Key Achievements and Analytical Work Under Private Sector Development Initiatives I and II

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative (PSDI) Phase III will follow on and 
build on the successes, lessons learned and strengths of the PSDI Phases I and II.12 These 
technical assistance (TA) projects support the Pacific Approach 2010–2014 and Strategy 2020 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and leverage ADB’s strategic focus on private sector 
development, with the objective of improving the business environment in Pacific developing 
member countries (DMCs).3 The first two phases of the PSDI focused on three core areas: (i) 
business law reform, (ii) improving access to financial services, and (iii) state-owned enterprise 
(SOE)  and  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  reforms.  The  positive  outcomes  of  the  PSDI 
initiatives in these areas have led to growing demand for assistance and an expansion of focus 
into the areas of competition policy and the economic empowerment of women.4 The TA design 
is  based  on  extensive  consultations  with  Pacific  DMC  governments,  private  sector  and 
development partners. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  It is difficult and costly to do business in the Pacific. Firms have to deal with isolation and 
small market size. There are many reasons why it is costly to start and operate a business in 
the Pacific. Business laws are outdated and unsuited to the needs of modern commerce. Laws 
governing contracts are confusing and difficult to enforce, and complying with regulations is 
costly and difficult. It is also hard for successful growing businesses to obtain the financing 
necessary to expand. The financial sector is generally not well developed, and access to and 
knowledge about financial services and their use by customers is typically limited. Informal 
sectors are large and productivity is low. While foreign investors should be a source of capital 
and knowledge, many countries make it hard for them to start new businesses. Inefficient SOEs 
dominate infrastructure service delivery, resulting in unreliable and costly utilities and transport 
services, which add to the high cost of doing business. Public sector investment achieves rates 
of return that are either low or negative. Many Pacific DMCs have competition frameworks that 
are  not  strong  enough  to  regulate  monopolies,  provide  poor  consumer  protection.  These 
constraints reduce private sector growth.  
 
3.  Women’s economic empowerment and economic development are closely interrelated. 
Limited economic opportunities for women result in higher opportunity cost in terms of foregone 
growth and poverty alleviation. Many barriers to women’s economic empowerment are systemic, 
being rooted in outdated laws or exclusionary economic and cultural practices.  
 
4.  All of the above factors reduce returns on investment, limiting flows of capital and 
technology  into  Pacific  island  economies,  and  restricting  growth  opportunities  that  could 
advance inclusive economic development, which reduces poverty.

5.  The reforms initiated under the PSDI I and II have strengthened the foundation for 
private sector development in the Pacific. The analytical work under the PSDI I and II identifies 
constraints to private entrepreneurship and investment as well as the constraints to women 
entering the formal sectors of Pacific DMCs. The findings of the analytical work have facilitated 
policy dialogue with Pacific DMC governments and private sectors on the direction and options 
for implementing policy changes. Indeed, the analytical support through the PSDI I and II has 
strongly complemented ADB’s policy-based financing operations, and there are new requests 
for assistance with private sector reforms in many Pacific DMCs. 
 
6.  PSDI  I  and  II  work  to-date  has  led  to  concrete  outcomes.  For  example,  secured 
transactions reform recognizes the challenges in many Pacific DMCs of using communal land 
as collateral, and assists countries to adopt alternative mechanisms to secure a loan with 
moveable properties. This has contributed regionally to more than 10,000 new loans issued by 
the banking sector. Another example is the establishment of an online company registry in the 
Solomon Islands which has helped to more than double yearly new company registrations. Also 
in the Solomon Islands, the PSDI has successfully supported the privatization of Sasape Marina. 
“PSDI owes its success to the flexibility of its operating model, the technical expertise and 
continuity of key expert involvement, the emphasis placed on research and analysis, and the 
coherence of its focus on institutions.” 6 The Supplementary Appendix gives an overview of 
major achievements and publications under the PSDI I and II.  
 
7.  As a driver of inclusive economic growth, a thriving private sector has become a national 
priority in many Pacific DMCs. Therefore, there is a keen interest among Pacific DMCs to 
extend analytical work to inform their national development strategies and reform activities. 
PSDI III will be instrumental in deepening and broadening critical reforms supported under PSDI 
I and II. Although many successful reforms have been initiated, there is strong demand from 
Pacific DMCs to substantially increase implementation support, extend work in core areas 
where limited reforms have occurred, and improve the business environment to enhance the 
competitiveness of Pacific DMCs. There is also an urgent need to assist entrepreneurs in the 
informal sector to formalize their businesses, opening opportunities to access formal financial 
institutions and to take advantage of the modernization of business laws. Geographically, this 
will cover all 14 Pacific DMCs, where appropriate. In Pacific fragile situations, experience has 
shown  that  reforming  the  business  environment  takes  many  years  and  requires  sustained 
political and policy support. A key feature of PSDI I and II and the proposed PSDI III is that they 
are demand driven, can respond quickly to requests from Pacific DMCs, and provide support 
until the reforms are fully implemented and tangible results are achieved.   
8.  Past  experience  highlights  the  importance  of  strengthening  synergy  among,  and 
effective coordination with, different regional programs and country operations. There is a need 
to work closely with ADB country team leaders so that the private sector components of ADB’s 
country partnership strategies and country operations business plans can be informed by the 
PSDI analytical work and reform initiatives can be aligned with policy-based loans and grants in 
the region. Effective coordination with other regional programs, such as the Pacific Regional 
Infrastructure  Facility  and  the  Pacific  Economic  Management  and  Pacific  Public  Financial 
Management  Initiatives  will  be  required  and  operational  linkages  with  the  Private  Sector 
Operations Department will need to be enforced. Coordination with the work of development 
partners, most importantly the Australian and New Zealand governments, will be essential.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The expected impact of the TA will be sustained economic growth in Pacific DMCs that 
increases  incomes.  The  expected  outcome  will  be  an  equitable  business  environment 
encouraging new business formation, and increased domestic and foreign investment in Pacific 
DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Output 1: Businesses and households in selected Pacific developing member 
countries  have  improved  access  to  financial  services.  The  PSDI will continue to help 
develop  innovative  financial  products  and  branchless  banking  models,  and  will  build  the 
capacity of financial institutions to deliver services sustainably. It will implement reforms that 
increase the ability of financial institutions to finance growing businesses and maintain financial 
sector stability. The TA will (i) further reform and implement secured transactions reforms and 
registries; (ii) review and advise on policies, laws, and regulations that are barriers to financial 
sector development; (iii) strengthen financial service providers and/or central banks through 
capacity building; and (iv) facilitate pilot testing of new financial products and delivery channels.  
 
11.  Output  2:  Selected  business  laws  in  Pacific  developing  member  countries 
promote  inclusive  business  formation,  investment,  entrepreneurship,  and  trade. 
Improving and simplifying business laws in Pacific DMCs will result in (i) the creation of new 
businesses, (ii) the expansion of existing ones, and (iii) easier entry for foreign investors. Poorer 
sections of the population and women will have improved access to formal business activity. 
Priorities  for  reform  in  the  business  law  area  include  the  establishment  of  new  business 
registries, new laws on insolvency, new trustee laws, further reforms of companies acts, and 
improvements in foreign investment regimes. 
 
12.   Output 3: The delivery of infrastructure services will be made more efficient and 
cost-effective. In most Pacific DMCs, a substantial portion of infrastructure services is provided 
by SOEs, which generally operate inefficiently and are a significant drain on the public budget. 
The  PSDI  will  continue  to  address  this  issue  through  the  implementation  of  SOE  reforms 
designed  to  improve  operating  efficiencies,  transparency,  and  accountability.  Where 
appropriate, the PSDI interventions will also facilitate the privatization of SOEs and/or the 
contracting out of their services. These contracts may be structured as PPPs.  
 
13.   Where new infrastructure investment is needed, the PSDI promotes private participation 
through PPPs involving activities covering the first three pillars of ADB’s PPP Operational Plan.7 
Under the PSDI I and II, substantial progress has been made in all three areas—in particular in 
Timor-Leste and Papua New Guinea, two countries with strong potential to develop formal PPP 
programs. The PSDI III will support the completion of the legal and regulatory frameworks for 
PPPs  in  these  two  countries,  the  establishment  of  institutional  capacity  to  manage  PPP 
programs, continued advocacy for PPPs throughout the Pacific, as well as the identification of 
and prefeasibility analysis for specific PPP transactions. The PSDI would not cover the PPP 
transaction advisory costs, but would support Pacific DMCs in recruiting transaction advisors 
                                                 
7  ADB. 2012. Public–Private Partnership Operational Plan, 2012–2020. Manila. The three pillars of the PPP 
Operational Plan include advocacy and capacity development, enabling environment, and project development.

4  
and providing ongoing transaction monitoring support. It is anticipated that the colocation of the 
Pacific Regional Infrastructure Facility and the PSDI will bring significant synergies. 
 
14.  Output 4: Selected Pacific developing member countries’ governments establish a 
framework that promotes competition. The small market size of Pacific DMCs leads to a 
small number of providers of products and services that are often inefficient and anticompetitive. 
The PSDI will assist selected Pacific DMCs to establish a framework that promotes competition 
and consumer protection. This includes preparing competition laws, establishing regulatory 
offices, and assisting with improving the capacity of regulators. 
 
15.   Output 5: Successful pilot initiatives promoting the economic empowerment of 
women are implemented in selected Pacific developing member countries. While the PSDI 
has a gender-mainstreamed approach across the core areas, where reform initiatives have 
ultimately gender benefits, the PSDI will carry out more specific gender-targeted research and 
pilot initiatives that contribute to the economic empowerment of women. Based on gender-
focused analytical work, the PSDI will identify areas for pilot initiatives in selected Pacific DMCs 
that will economically empower women and have a demonstration effect for replication and up-
scaling.  Specific  activities  to  promote  the  economic  empowerment  of  women  will  include 
diagnostic work to identify and remove constraints on women’s advancement,8 implementing 
pilot programs to test alternative modalities to promote opportunities for women, and utilizing the 
findings to: (i) scale up these initiatives, and (ii) disseminate lessons learned as knowledge 
products. This will include providing women with better access to markets. 
 
16.  Output 6: Strategic and knowledge management services are effectively provided. 
The  relevance  and  effectiveness  of  the  PSDI  interventions  rests  on  in-depth  analysis  of 
constraints  to  doing  business  in  Pacific  DMCs.  As  the  program  expands,  monitoring  and 
evaluation (M&E) will be expanded to include selected impact evaluations, and attention will be 
paid to knowledge sharing across the Pacific. The PSDI III will continue to undertake private 
sector assessments to identify and prioritize further reforms that will be incorporated into the 
PSDI III outputs, and support formalization of partnership agreements of development partners 
and ADB’s country programming. Knowledge-sharing workshops will disseminate findings and 
lessons, and the M&E framework will track progress of all the PSDI III initiatives. An annual 
review and strategic planning meeting with selected ADB staff and development partners will 
facilitate strategic focus and work programs. Bulletins describing issues and outcomes of the 
PSDI initiatives will be published several times a year. Key lessons will be disseminated through 
printed and social media. Regular private sector roundtables will facilitate discussions between 
public and private sector stakeholders. Conferences will be used to disseminate findings in each 
focus area. The PSDI core team members will continue to participate regularly in regional and 
international  conferences  to  discuss  findings  and  best  practices.  A  comprehensive  M&E 
framework is an integral part of the PSDI—monitoring TA outputs and outcomes. The results 
are aggregated and described in the PSDI annual progress report. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $30,500,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-V),  $24,000,000  by  the 
Government of Australia, and $4,500,000 by the Government of New Zealand, and will be 
administered by ADB. Options to source additional cofinancing will be explored. Detailed cost 
estimates and financing plans are in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB, as the executing agency, will further strengthen the accountability and monitoring 
and evaluation mechanism of this TA. This includes a project administration unit in the Pacific 
Liaison and Coordination Office (PLCO).The project administration unit comprises ADB sector 
specialists  and  administrative  staff  and  will  be  under  the  direct  supervision  of  the  PLCO 
Regional  Director.  The  project  administration  unit  will  undertake  (i)  project  and  program 
management, (ii) financial management responsibilities, (iii) fiduciary responsibilities and (iv) 
monitoring and evaluation of progress. The TA will be implemented over 6 years from June 
2013 to May 2019. The TA will require a total of 837 person-months of international consultants 
and  150  person-months  of  national  consultants.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 14 full-time consultants—10 international (608 person-months) and four national (150 
person-months)—will  be  hired  following  individual  consultant  selection.9 Areas  of  expertise 
include  (i)  private  sector  development  strategies  and  policies,  (ii)  competition  policies,  (iii) 
economic empowerment of women, (iv) SOE reform, (v) PPPs, (vi) business law reform, (vii) 
regulatory reform, (viii) access to finance, (ix) knowledge management and communication, (x) 
M&E,  and  (xi)  flexible  results-oriented  innovative  grant  delivery.10 In-country  private  sector 
development  coordinators  (international  and/or  national  consultants)  may  be  recruited  as 
appropriate.11 Specialized  short-term  consultants  (international,  229  person-months)  will  be 
recruited by a combination of individual consultant selection and indefinite delivery contract. 12    
 
19.  To  ensure  compatibility  and  consistency  with  electronic  registry  platforms  and 
applications that have been designed and implemented under the PSDI I and II, consultants or 
firms previously hired under the PSDI will not be excluded from consideration. The New Zealand 
Companies Office, responsible for designing and implementing Infrastructure as a Service for 
business registries in the Pacific, will be sole-sourced to provide additional implementation 
support to the infrastructure and electronic business registries. If adaptation of registries that are 
already operational is required, ideally this will be done by the same consultant or firm. Training, 
workshops, and conferences will be implemented through PLCO and the selected consultants. 
PLCO  will  procure  all  office  space,  equipment,  and  materials  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB staff may be used as 
resource persons, in which case their travel costs would be charged to the TA. TA proceeds will 
be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). Detailed financial management arrangements will be established in 
consultation with relevant and concerned ADB. A yearly external financial audit of the project 
financial statements will be carried out by an independent auditor.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
20.  The President recommends that the Board approve (i) ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $30,500,000 to be financed on a grant 
basis by the Governments of Australia ($24,000,000) and New Zealand ($4,500,000); and (ii) 
ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for the 
Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative, Phase III.

1.2.  Expand access to financial services. 
1.2.1. Undertake financial sector assessments, legal diagnostics of financial sector laws, and regulations. 
1.2.2. Reform laws, regulations, and policies in at least two Pacific DMCs.

2.  Selected business laws in Pacific DMCs promote inclusive business formation, investment, 
entrepreneurship, and trade  
2.1.  Reform commercial laws.  
2.1.1. Undertake at least seven country consultations on business law reform issues.

2.2.  Establish business registries.

2.2.2. Organize two regional conferences for staff of national registries in the Pacific and selected other countries. 
2.3.  Identify legal constraints to the economic empowerment of women.  
3.  The delivery of infrastructure services will be made more efficient and cost-effective   
3.1.  Undertake SOE reforms.  
3.1.1. Measure rates of return on SOEs in at least eight countries in the region by 2019. 
3.1.2. Publish three further SOE benchmarking studies by 2019. 
3.1.3. Conduct at least 25 SOE director training sessions by 2019. 
3.1.4. Prepare at least four SOE laws or substantial amendments to existing SOE laws by 2019. 
3.1.5. Support the implementation of community service obligation frameworks in at least three countries by 2019. 
3.1.6. Complete at least four privatization transactions by 2019.  
3.2.  Facilitate the implementation of selected PPPs.   
3.2.1. Prepare at least two PPP legal frameworks by 2019. 
3.2.2. Support the establishment of PPP units in PNG and Timor-Leste by 2019. 
3.2.3. Identify PPP transaction opportunities in at least five countries by 2019 (completed pre-feasibility). 
3.2.4. Facilitate the development of five PPP transactions by 2019.

selected Pacific DMCs

5.2.  Utilize the findings to design at least four gender pilot initiatives.  
5.3.  Evaluate pilot initiatives to identify success factors promoting the economic empowerment of women. 
5.4.  Assist ADB and other development partners in replicating and scaling up successful pilot initiatives.

KEY ACHIEVEMENTS AND ANALYTICAL WORK UNDER PRIVATE SECTOR 
DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVES I AND II 
 
 
1.  In its first 6 years of operation, PSDI concentrated on 3 focus areas; (i) improving access 
to finance and financial services, (ii) improving the business law frameworks of Pacific DMCs, 
and (iii) strengthening SOE governance and assisting with privatizations and in establishing a 
foundation for PPP transactions. It has achieved notable success in each of these areas. 
 
A.  Access to Finance and Financial Services 
 
2.  Secured  transactions  reforms.  One  of  PSDI’s  major  achievements  in  access  to 
finance has been the reform of secured transactions frameworks in 8 Pacific DMCS. This is the 
most extensive program of successful reform in the world. Starting with the Federated States of 
Micronesia (FSM) in 2006,1 6 Pacific DMCs have completed their reforms,2 the most recent 
being Palau, which opened its electronic registry in early 2013. Papua New Guinea and Samoa 
have also passed new laws but have not yet implemented them because the registries have not 
yet been installed.  
 
3.  In all of these countries, PSDI provided assistance in obtaining electronic registries and 
implementing the new framework. As a result of the new secured transactions frameworks, 
financial institutions in the countries where they have occurred have provided over 10,000 new 
formal sector loans.  
 
4.  Financial  outreach  and  branchless  banking.  A  significant  obstacle  to  increasing 
access to financial services in rural areas has been the high cost of establishing traditional 
banking networks versus the low revenue that low-income and rural customers generate for 
financial institutions. A central part of PSDI’s efforts to improve access to finance has and 
continues to be the increase in financial outreach through innovative products and delivery 
methods. The rapid growth in mobile phone coverage in the Pacific provides an opportunity to 
extend financial services to a far broader section of the population than was possible before. 
PSDI has actively supported financial outreach through its work on branchless banking. It has 
supported financial institutions in PNG and Timor-Leste to develop branchless banking models. 
In PNG, Nationwide Microbank launched an innovative mobile phone–linked bank account, 
MiCash, which enables customers to deposit and withdraw funds from their bank account 
through an agent network, without having to travel to a bank branch, and to transfer funds to 
friends and family who also have a bank account with Nationwide Microbank. This has reduced 
transaction costs, increased security, and greatly improved the ease of accessing financial 
services.  
 
5.  PSDI provided support for (i) a review of the MiCash pilot in West New Britain Province, 
(ii) the development of appropriate audit and risk management processes for MiCash, and (iii) 
the  development  of  a  training  program  for  staff  and  agents.  In  August  2012,  Nationwide 
Microbank won the 2012 PNG Institute of Directors Award for the most innovative company of 
the year for its MiCash product. Over 10,000 new customers now have a MiCash account and 
can  now  deposit  and  withdraw  funds  through  more  than  120  agents  and  branches,

6.  Increased access to bank accounts. Assistance to microfinance institutions in PNG, 
Timor-Leste and Vanuatu has resulted in a significant growth in savings accounts, particularly in

7.  PSDI also provides assistance for legal and regulatory environment for deposit-taking

B.  Business Law Reform  
 
8.  Analytical work undertaken by PSDI revealed that business laws in the Pacific are often 
outdated, being based on commercial law imported from the United Kingdom. This is, however, 
changing rapidly as a result of PSDI legal reforms, which are having the effect of making the 
business law framework far more inclusive.  
 
9.  Company  registries.  Assistance  provided  by  PSDI  includes  the  transformation  of 
paper-based company registries to those that are electronic and internet-based. This has the 
effect  of  broadening  access  to  legal  facilities  to  any  area  that  has  Internet  connectivity—
something that is expanding rapidly in many countries in the region. Business law reforms in 
Solomon  Islands  facilitated  a  new  innovative  Company  Act  and  registry,  which  enables 
companies to be registered in less than 2 days. As a result the number of new business 
registrations has more than doubled (from 127 to 290) since the inception of the new electronic 
registry in 2010. The cost of registering a company dropped from $336 to $175 and was a 
leading factor in Solomon Islands being identified as one of the top reformers in the 2012 World 
Bank Doing Business Indicators.  
 
10.  Community companies. A unique feature of the new Solomon Islands Companies Act, 
which will be expanded into other countries in the region, is the provision that allows for the 
formation  of  community  companies,  which  support  community-based  businesses  that  are 
intended to preserve and grow community assets into the future. The community company has 
many advantages over cooperatives or trusts because they provide for far greater transparency 
and protection of community assets. They are a powerful instrument for promoting inclusive 
growth and opportunity, particularly for women’s groups.  
 
C.  State-Owned Enterprise Reform  
 
11.  Analytical work undertaken on SOE performance in the region identified SOEs as a 
significant factor reducing growth and productivity. Although they control nearly one third of the 
capital stocks in Pacific DMCs they contribute on average less than 10% of output as a result of 
political influence, over-staffing, poor transparency, and accountability and a lack of commercial 
focus.  
 
12.  PSDI’s work in SOE reform and PPPs aims at placing SOEs on a more commercial, 
transparent,  and  profitable  footing,  while  facilitating  opportunities  for  the  private  sector  to 
provide infrastructure and related services. PSDI’s work addresses the inefficiency of SOEs

Supplementary Appendix       17 
through  improving  governance,  strengthening  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  SOE 
operation,  and  through  the  restructuring  and/or  privatizing  of  SOEs.  Some  examples  of 
assistance include support to the Ministry of Finance in Solomon Islands to select management 
and directors of SOEs, training sessions for SOE directors in Tonga and Samoa and the 
implementation of Community Service Obligation guidelines in a number DMCs.  
 
13.  The ongoing SOE reform efforts are beginning to show promising results, with the total 
fiscal transfers to SOEs dropping for the first time in fiscal year 2009 in the 4 of the 6 countries 
benchmarked. Improvement continued in 2011, the latest year for which data are available.  
 
14.  PSDI I and II assisted Pacific DMCs with the privatization of 7 loss-making enterprises 
and  the  improvement  in  corporate  governance  and  accountability  of  many  more.  As  an 
example, in Solomon Islands the sale of Sasape Marina to private operators, resulted in over 
150 jobs being saved and the continuation of the only significant ship repair facility in Solomon 
Islands. PSDI support to the Tonga biosecurity heat treatment facility, which was formerly 
operated by the Ministry of Agriculture resulted in Tonga fruit and vegetables being exported to 
New Zealand, is an example of successful corporatization and commercialization.  
 
15.  Public–private partnerships. PPPs have become a central theme in reform in Pacific 
DMCs, not only in PSDI but also in ADB’s Pacific Department more generally. In spite of 
significant inputs under PSDI, PPPs have generally been embryonic in the region and only in 
2012 were beginning to achieve momentum. Some examples include (i) in Timor-Leste, a PPP 
policy and draft law was finalized in 2011 and endorsed by the Cabinet in early 2012; and (ii) in 
PNG, a draft PPP bill was finalized in 2011 and now awaits submission to Parliament. These 
legal frameworks will provide the basis for preparing PPP transactions in a transparent and 
predictable manner, allowing a PPP program to develop that will reduce the risks of participation 
by the private sector.   
 
16.  While  the  frameworks  are  being  developed,  PPP  transactions  are  being  prepared, 
including the operation and maintenance contracts in the water and wastewater sectors in 
Timor-Leste and Vanuatu, the power sector in Timor-Leste, and the port sector in PNG. PSDI’s 
PPP assessment for PNG’s Lae Port resulted in the government’s commitment to operate the 
port under a PPP arrangement in the future. This work complements a large ADB investment in 
Lae Port. PSDI also conducted PPP assessments of 22 potential infrastructure projects in 
Timor-Leste in collaboration with the International Finance Corporation. This resulted in 4 pre-
feasibility studies.  
 
D.  Cross Cutting Themes 
 
17.  Gender.  PSDI actively considers gender issues when initiating reforms. Through its 
comprehensive  M&E  framework,  PSDI  tracks  gender  impact  using  the  ADB  gender 
classification framework. All of PSDI’s initiatives promote gender benefits, with 45 of the 70 
initiatives classified as either category GEN or EGM. PSDI has collected significant anecdotal 
evidence of the substantial gender effects of the company law reform in Solomon Islands, in 
particular from the provision of community companies. In PNG and Timor-Leste, there has been 
a large increase in bank accounts opened and held by women. Before these facilities became 
available, many women opening accounts had never been in control of their own finances. 
 
18.  Analytical work. Reform initiatives under PSDI are based on a substantial foundation of 
analytical work. To date 6 private sector assessments have been undertaken or updated under 
PSDI I and II and are used to ensure that reforms are effective and to reestablish priorities on a
